interlinear-text.item: GSK Le Meunier Chauve et le Renard

phrase.item: Once upon a time there was a bald miller, and near his mill there were grapes.
A fox came at night to eat these grapes.
Early in the morning, the bald miller went out: his grapes had been eaten.
He thought: "I will watch (look out) at night to see who's eating my grapes."
Either a use of pajra as a verb, or a mistranscription, or the "m" is the clitic, which is also odd...
One night he was on the lookout and caught the fox red handed.
He said: "Hey fox, all I have is this vine and the mill.
By dint of coming and eating my grapes at night, you've ruined me.
He [the fox] said: "Bald miller, do not raise your voice, I will marry you to a king's daughter."
The fox left to go to the king for the marriage proposal.
During the day he would hide and at night with his tail he swept the royal palace ' like a teacup ' (impecably).
Each morning the king got up: The palace has been swept 'exactly like a porcelain teacup!' (perfectly clean)
He thought: " Who is sweeping my palace so perfectly?"
He said to the guards: "Watch out (spy) today; who is sweeping like this?"
The guards spotted the fox, caught him and brought him to the king.
They said: "O king, it appears that it's a fox who was getting ready to sweep."
The king asked him: "What do you need?"
He said: "I have come to marry your daughter to a son of a king."
The king ordered: "Kill him, is it possible for a fox to serve as a matchmaker?
How come, instead of sending a fox, this king's son didn't come himself?"
The vizier said: "O king!
Do not kill a fox, foxes are very wise.
Demand that he brings you forty mules laden with gold.
He will leave and never return.

Where would he find forty mules laden with gold ? He will never return for this marriage!" He asked for forty mules laden with gold from the fox and he left, returned to the miller and said: " Hey, miller!
The king demanded forty mules laden with gold from me."
The miller said: "It doesn't matter to me anyway, where will I pull forty mules laden with gold out from?"

(The fox said: "And me, I will find [them.]") The fox left at night, gathered potsherds and debris (gravel, sand) in forty sacks, took forty donkeys out from different stables during the night, packed the debris and potsherds on the donkeys, went with the miller to the edge of a river and said "You stay here on the [river] bank, I will go to the king, ask him to go out to the top of a tower: "O king!
I brought you forty loaded donkeys."
You'll go in the water with the donkeys and you'll slice the tendons of their legs."
He himself left ahead, [and] arrived at the king's [palace].
He said: "O king!
These forty loaded donkeys that you asked of me, here they are, I brought them to you.
Come out, climb a tower, look!"
The king and the fox went out , forty loaded donkeys arrived, entered the river and drowned in the river.
He said: "Hey king!
My load sank in this river.
Now what must I do for you?"
He said: I saw your load sink in the river, go get your fiancé"
The fox said: O king!
The water has also carried away the clothes of my fiancé."
The king ordered: "Go get clothes, [and] give them to him."
They left, took clothes from the king, gave them to the fox.
The fox brought them to the river's edge and dressed the bald miller.

He said: "Bald miller, do not eat a lot, don't look amazed upon seeing the palace, don't widen your eyes when you see your clothes, if not it will be my shame: what is this king's son who hasn't seen good food, hasn't seen beautiful clothes, hasn't seen a grand palace, in his life?"
As soon as the fox brought him to the court, he looked at his clothes.
One of the parents of the king said: "Fox!
Your king's son, how is it possible that he hasn't seen clothes in his life?"
He said: "He had clothes all embroidered with gold.
This garment here isn't anything compared to what he's seen."
He said: "And why is he examining the palace so much?"
He responded: "He has a palace where the walls are decorated with pearls and precious stones."
And they put faith in all of this, they found the fox's words to be truthful.
And now they brought him some rice, for him a large serving is a handful.
Once again they asked the fox: "Who is this, is he really legitimate: an entire plate of rice, isn't even a handful for him?"
sovaʝd (also not in the dictionary)
The fox responded: " Where he comes from they cook rice for him in such a way that there is only oil (butter.)"
And they believed him.
The nuptial rites were performed, [and] in the morning they said their goodbyes and left; now the fox needs to worry about the house: "If I bring the princess to the mill, she won't stay."
He said: "Hey you bald guy, cursed be thy father! How many complications you cause me!
If I bring the princess to the mill now, she won't stay."
On his way, the fox came across the palace of a blind madman.
He said: "You follow me, while hitting the drums and tambourines and I'll go ahead."
He went ahead, got to the palace of the blind madman and approached him; just then the sounds from the drums and tambourines reached the ears of the blind madman.
He said: "Hey fox!
What's that noise?"
"Cover yourself (hide) in a burrow (hole)"
He said - "It's a dragon that has appeared, he has already swallowed the entire world , your palace is all that's left."
He said: "Hey fox!
Hide me first, you're small, a groove (a small space) will be enough for you."
The fox said: "I'm worried about myself, let alone you."
He said: "Hey fox, let me die before you, first hide me!"
The madman had a lot of hay.
The fox told him:" Dig into the hay, slide yourself inside, I'll cover you up with hay and you will hide there; as long as the sounds persist, you'll stay there!"
He said: "Understood!"
He dug into the hay, the fox hid him, approached a match, [and] set it on fire: the madman burned and was transformed to coal (ash.)
The fox brought the princess and the bald miller [to the palace] and set them up on the throne.
The fox said: "Hey bald miller!
Now you will listen to me!
You lived in a mill, I married you to a princess, I seized the castle of a madman for you and I put you on a royal throne."
The fox stayed with them for some time.
One day he pretended to be sick.
And another day he [also pretended] he was sick and the bald miller said : "Throw the fox out, throw him on the street, he infected all of the palace!"
They took the fox by the paws, [and] at that moment he perked up and said: "Ah you are cursed bald miller!
You, the bald miller, sitting at your mill until night, you couldn't even find bread to feed yourself, or clothes to to dress yourself.
I gave you a princess, the castle of a madman that I captured for you and now you've lost all reason, you say: "you smell!?""
He said: "Hey princess, you can leave."
The princess got up and left.
The miller fell at his feet once again and began to cry and to beg.
The fox left to bring back the princess.
He went to get the princess and shouted to her: "Hey, shepheard's daughter, where are you going?"
The princess decided that he must be [one] as the fox said and she retraced her steps (went back) with him.
He brought her to their palace.
The fox said: "Now I am going to fall ill and when I die, take my corpse and burn it.
Gather the ashes in a small pile, place a stone on top, and leave them [there] for a week.
After one week lift the stone, you will see what's there!"
When the fox died, the bald miller burned him, gathered the ashes in a pile, placed a stone on top.
He left them for one week, came back after one week, lifted the stone, the ash had transformed into a gold ring.
So he took this ring, went in his palace with the princess and lived hapily ever after on the throne.
